title: Art at bus stops quite the draw
text:
GEORGE TOWN: The art on the back panels of two bus stops in Penang are attracting attention, especially with Thaipusam on Feb 9. 
In the illustrations, devotees are seen climbing up the Arulmigu Balathan­dayuthapani Hilltop Temple as they carry kavadis during Thaipusam. 
There are also scenes of a milkman and a sundry shop.
The two bus stops, one located along Burmah Road near the junction with Edgecumbe Road and the other at the beginning of Tanjung Tokong Road, are among 10 bus stops in the Pulau Tikus state constituency which have drawings that showcase different communities in the constituency.
Pulau Tikus assemblyman Yap Soo Huey said the illustrations at the bus stops were part of a “community stories” project under the “Connecting with Our Heritage” initiative run by her office.
She said the illustrations at the other bus stops depicted stories from the Eurasian, Chinese, Malay, Thai and Burmese communities, with two bus stops having the same illustrations of each community.
Meanwhile, sculpting work on the 13.71m-high entrance arch at the hilltop temple in Jalan Kebun Bunga is completed.
Temple chairman R. Subramaniam said prayers for the arch would be conducted today.
Subramaniam said painting work on the arch would likely begin in two months.
